reviews.review_text: Is this game better than Euro Truck Simulator 2? --- That depends what you are looking for.  I got into the truck driving simulator series when I was curious about my skills being able to operate a trailer and take tight turns. I have yet to see a game that puts you in a city situation where you have really check your space margins when taking a right turn next to traffic.   Euro Truck simulator seems to focus more on highway driving and has a bit of city driving when you get near the warehouse. Thing is though, seems like warehouses are the only things that make up the cities. I bought Scania for the reason mentioned above about city situations, I wanted to be driving in tight situations where turns would be difficult. The game gives a few options regarding driving such as free drive mode (where you pick up a trailer and deliver it, more like time trial mode), driver license where you go through a tough licensing course, driver competition to test your accuracy around obstacles, and my favorite and reason why I bought this game : dangerous drives. Dangerous drives put you in situations where you must drive your truck or cargo through super tight scenarios (such as driving along side of a cliff). My favorite feature of this game setting is that the devs seemed to try to incorporate everyday life scenarios into this mode. One challenge requires the player to back up their truck behind the stage of a rock show, and attach to a trailer, do a 180 through a bunch of parked cars and other band trailers, and drive away.   The controller bindings for this game are absolutely beautiful once you figure it out. I wish more games had this much control over controller settings.   Visuals are nice neat and relevant to trucking. No hiccups or gaps here. Sounds are generic as trucks are all the same brand.   Although I would put it on par with Euro Truck 2, I would say if Euro Truck had dangerous drives I would have most likely skipped over this game and kept with that one. That being said, I would still like to see a truck driving simulating game that puts the player in a city where they have to make turns in busy pedestrian and traffic scenarios. Sure it would be hard to make entire maps for cities, but even have a few to choose from with a few tight roads to outmaneuver through would be cool.   I feel Euro Truck has given in their game a bit more to do, and for that it's rating will be higher than this games. None the less, great purchase on sale. Brief Review    A truck driving simulator might not sound like the most exciting of games out there, but Scania is very much a game. This isn’t just another delivery simulation. The crux of Scania Truck Driving Simulator is maneuvering your big rig through a number of dangerous situations and hazardous courses filled with real-life obstacles. You’ll be put into critical situations where flooding or the aftermath of an earthquake, play a part in compromising what would normally be a direct and hazard free delivery route    Pros and Cons     Pros   Great Fun Addictive Gameplay Great Graphics Kid Friendly Leadboards Competitive   Cons   Cant Think Of Any    An Ending    Prove your truck skills - Put your driving skills to the ultimate test

STDS is far more punishing to novice drivers. If you think backing a trailer is hard in ETS2, just wait until you experience the rage-fuelled exercise in misery that attempting the same in STDS turns out to be. Your gear-shifting has to be more accurate, your stopping distances longer, and if you're anything like me, you'll stall the truck roughly 285 times during hill-starts or when manoeuvring at low speed. (Planting your foot on the accelerator for a couple of seconds before releasing the clutch rapidly becomes a way of life.) And if you think you can just hook up a trailer and trundle off in 4th gear like you do in ETS2... I'm afraid not. The Scania you have in STDS is powered by an emaciated hamster with a respiratory infection, and he just can't turn that driveshaft fast enough.  Compared to this, ETS2 is child's play. You spend the vast majority of your time cruising down the Autobahn listening to Def Leppard. In STDS, you're navigating tiny cargo yards strewn with pallets and forkhoists, or squeezing down narrow side streets between parked cars and roadworks. And then, if you actually manage to get to your destination without ploughing into a field or getting yourself stuck in a hedge, you'll spend the next 20 minutes performing a 27 point turn in a cack-handed attempt to slot the trailer into the crevice left between another trailer and those barrels some git left sitting in the middle of the yard.  Most of the truck drivers I know swear a lot. If there was such a thing as the 'profanity olympics', they'd be gold medallists. Now that I've played STDS, I know why. Having said that, it's a lot of fun. You do, after a few hours spent shrieking like a lunatic and cursing the laws of physics, get the hang of it. I can now make deliveries without causing a multiple car pile up in the middle of an intersection. I can navigate the city (no GPS for you, young man) pretty well, and I can even reverse my trailer into position without stalling, punching a hole through a fence or reducing a pedestrian to an unsightly crimson smear on the pavement. I still can't parallel park. But then I can barely parallel park my car, so I'm not that fussed to be honest.  To sum up, STDS is basically ETS2 with mushy controls, crappy force feedback, slightly dodgy physics, somewhat underwhelming audio (the Scania doesn't so much roar as mewl piteously), no career mode, a much smaller map, and a learning curve so steep you'll need a velcro wetsuit dipped in PVA glue to have even a hope of scaling it. Unlike ETS2, it forces you to drive properly -- pay attention to your mirrors, shift gears at the right time, make tiny adjustments to the steering wheel when manoeuvring, and practice, practice, practice. Because it really is a simulator (as well as being a gloriously shameless advertising campaign for Scania), as opposed to a scenic tour of Europe by truck. I love both games, and for completely different reasons, but I would recommend STDS to die-hard truck driving fans, Scania fetishists and masochists only. This is a game that will kick you in the crotch and then laugh about it, but if you're willing to spend the time (and we're talking a lot of time here) mastering it, it may eventually shake your hand and buy you a pint.  Maybe.
